text: A character from this country has his plans thwarted when his brother-in-law publishes an article under the name “Defender of the Morality.” The protagonist of a novel from this country purchases an ox for companionship after living to see his entire family die. In a novel from this country, an army doctor spends 18 years trying to divorce his wife. This country is the setting of the depressing novels To Live and (*) Waiting, as well as a novel whose protagonist gets his lazy aunt and uncle addicted to opium. The protagonist of that novel set in this country marries a slave and has three sons, who he supports by pulling a rickshaw and acquiring land. For 10 points, Pearl Buck’s The Good Earth is set in what country, the home of authors Yu Hua and Ha Jin?
answer: China [or People’s Republic of China; or PRC; or Zhōngguo or Zhōnggua] <ML, Long Fiction>   Bonuses
formatted_text: A character from this country has his plans thwarted when his brother-in-law publishes an article under the name “Defender of the Morality.” The protagonist of a novel from this country purchases an ox for companionship after living to see his entire family die. In a novel from this country, an army doctor spends 18 years trying to divorce his wife. This country is the setting of the depressing novels To Live and (*) Waiting, as well as a novel whose protagonist gets his lazy aunt and uncle addicted to opium. The protagonist of that novel set in this country marries a slave and has three sons, who he supports by pulling a rickshaw and acquiring land. For 10 points, Pearl Buck’s The Good Earth is set in what country, the home of authors Yu Hua and Ha Jin?
formatted_answer: China [or People’s Republic of China; or PRC; or Zhōngguo or Zhōnggua] <ML, Long Fiction> Bonuses

text: In one novel, a character who prevents these events dresses up as an old hag to get past Sergeant Bibot and tricks his arch-enemy Chauvelin by offering him a snuff box full of pepper. Prior to one of these events, the protagonist of another novel is told “You comfort me so much! I am so ignorant” before being kissed by an unnamed seamstress. The foppish Percy Blakeney prevents these events under a (*) secret identity in Baroness Emma Orczy’s (“ORT-see’s”) series about “the Scarlet Pimpernel.” In another novel, Madame Defarge knits the names of people who participate in these events. Prior to one of these events, a lawyer notes “It is a far, far better thing that I do, than I have ever done.” For 10 points, Sydney Carton takes Charles Darnay’s place in what sort of event at the end of Charles Dickens’ A Tale of Two Cities?
answer: executions by guillotine [or guillotinings; or beheadings; prompt on deaths] <RK, Long Fiction>
formatted_text: In one novel, a character who prevents these events dresses up as an old hag to get past Sergeant Bibot and tricks his arch-enemy Chauvelin by offering him a snuff box full of pepper. Prior to one of these events, the protagonist of another novel is told “You comfort me so much! I am so ignorant” before being kissed by an unnamed seamstress. The foppish Percy Blakeney prevents these events under a (*) secret identity in Baroness Emma Orczy’s (“ORT-see’s”) series about “the Scarlet Pimpernel.” In another novel, Madame Defarge knits the names of people who participate in these events. Prior to one of these events, a lawyer notes “It is a far, far better thing that I do, than I have ever done.” For 10 points, Sydney Carton takes Charles Darnay’s place in what sort of event at the end of Charles Dickens’ A Tale of Two Cities?
formatted_answer: executions by guillotine [or guillotinings; or beheadings; prompt on deaths] <RK, Long Fiction>

text: A poem about this conflict quotes Horace’s line “Knock at a star with my exalted head” and is titled “The Bad Season Makes The Poet Sad.” A ballad composed during this conflict notes “Old Christmas is kickt out of town” and includes the refrain “Yet let’s be content.” A poet justified fighting in a prelude to this conflict with the lines “I could not love thee (Dear) so much / loved I not honor more.” That author described how “Love with unconfinèd wings / Hovers within my gates” in a poem about his arrest in this conflict that concludes (*) “Stone Walls do not a Prison make.” The collection Hesperides was published during this conflict and includes the carpe diem poem “To the Virgins, to Make Much of Time.” For 10 points, Richard Lovelace and Robert Herrick were named “Cavalier Poets” for supporting Charles I in what conflict?
answer: English Civil War [or Wars of the Three Kingdoms; or British Civil War] (The second line refers to the ballad “The World Turned Upside Down.”) <JM, Poetry>
formatted_text: A poem about this conflict quotes Horace’s line “Knock at a star with my exalted head” and is titled “The Bad Season Makes The Poet Sad.” A ballad composed during this conflict notes “Old Christmas is kickt out of town” and includes the refrain “Yet let’s be content.” A poet justified fighting in a prelude to this conflict with the lines “I could not love thee (Dear) so much / loved I not honor more.” That author described how “Love with unconfinèd wings / Hovers within my gates” in a poem about his arrest in this conflict that concludes (*) “Stone Walls do not a Prison make.” The collection Hesperides was published during this conflict and includes the carpe diem poem “To the Virgins, to Make Much of Time.” For 10 points, Richard Lovelace and Robert Herrick were named “Cavalier Poets” for supporting Charles I in what conflict?
formatted_answer: English Civil War [or Wars of the Three Kingdoms; or British Civil War] (The second line refers to the ballad “The World Turned Upside Down.”) <JM, Poetry>

text: This economist collaborated with William James Adams in a 1976 paper arguing against allowing monopolies in bundled commodities. This economist has the alphabetically later surname in a 2004 paper arguing that Robert Lucas’s critique of Keynesian (“CANE-zee-in”) stabilization policy is inaccurate because workers would be worse off unemployed in a recession than during a boom. In one position, this economist oversaw a process called “unwinding the balance sheet,” which was the (*) sell-off of assets acquired during a period of quantitative easing. This economist co-authored many of her famous papers with her husband, George Akerlof, before Barack Obama appointed her to her most famous role. For 10 points, name this Federal Reserve Chair from 2014 to 2018.
answer: Janet Louise Yellen <AA, Social Science: Econ>
formatted_text: This economist collaborated with William James Adams in a 1976 paper arguing against allowing monopolies in bundled commodities. This economist has the alphabetically later surname in a 2004 paper arguing that Robert Lucas’s critique of Keynesian (“CANE-zee-in”) stabilization policy is inaccurate because workers would be worse off unemployed in a recession than during a boom. In one position, this economist oversaw a process called “unwinding the balance sheet,” which was the (*) sell-off of assets acquired during a period of quantitative easing. This economist co-authored many of her famous papers with her husband, George Akerlof, before Barack Obama appointed her to her most famous role. For 10 points, name this Federal Reserve Chair from 2014 to 2018.

text: In this country, a clenched red fist made up the logo of a dissident group of auto workers. In this country, labor unrest that happened in early 1970 was known as the “Hot Autumn.” A crime in this country was discussed by Carlos the Jackal during talks in an airport in Beirut. That crime involved a mediator of the “Historic Compromise” in this country being (*) kidnapped. The “Clean Hands” investigation in the 1990s led to the downfall of this country’s Christian Democracy party. In this country, Aldo Moro was kidnapped during a period known as the Years of Lead. Strikes at the main Fiat plants happened in this country in its city of Turin. For 10 points, name this country that recently saw the political rise of Silvio Berlusconi, owner of a soccer club in its city of Milan.
answer: Italy [or Italia; or Italian Republic] <ML, European History>
formatted_text: In this country, a clenched red fist made up the logo of a dissident group of auto workers. In this country, labor unrest that happened in early 1970 was known as the “Hot Autumn.” A crime in this country was discussed by Carlos the Jackal during talks in an airport in Beirut. That crime involved a mediator of the “Historic Compromise” in this country being (*) kidnapped. The “Clean Hands” investigation in the 1990s led to the downfall of this country’s Christian Democracy party. In this country, Aldo Moro was kidnapped during a period known as the Years of Lead. Strikes at the main Fiat plants happened in this country in its city of Turin. For 10 points, name this country that recently saw the political rise of Silvio Berlusconi, owner of a soccer club in its city of Milan.

text: In one play, a character whispers that he has hidden one of these objects in a cellar during a conversation with a nurse in which he laments not having eaten noodles for ages. At the end of that play’s third act, a man tosses one of these objects on the floor and collapses in a chair after struggling over it with Helena. At the end of another play, Doctor Dorn claims one of his medicine bottles made a sound that was actually from one of these objects, in order to calm (*) Irina Arkadina (“ar-KAH-dee-nah”). A hypothetical one of these objects that is hung on a wall in the first act names a literary maxim according to which every element of a story should contribute to its plot. For 10 points, give these objects, the subject of an Anton Chekhov proverb stating that if one is introduced to a play, it must be fired later.
answer: guns [accept Chekhov’s gun; accept pistol or rifle] (The plays are Uncle Vanya and The Seagull.) <WA, Drama>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses

At the end of another play, Doctor Dorn claims one of his medicine bottles made a sound that was actually from one of these objects, in order to calm (*) Irina Arkadina (“ar-KAH-dee-nah”). A hypothetical one of these objects that is hung on a wall in the first act names a literary maxim according to which every element of a story should contribute to its plot. For 10 points, give these objects, the subject of an Anton Chekhov proverb stating that if one is introduced to a play, it must be fired later.
formatted_answer: guns [accept Chekhov’s gun; accept pistol or rifle] (The plays are Uncle Vanya and The Seagull.) <WA, Drama> If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions. Bonuses

text: In this country, 192 olive and cypress trees constitute a “Forest of Remembrance” that was created after a terrorist attack. After his assassination in a bombing, one politician from this country was nicknamed as this country’s “first astronaut.” In this country, a car was launched over a building during Operation Ogre, which assassinated a leader of the far right búnker faction, Luis (*) Carrero Blanco. The pro-Iraq War Popular Party and its leader, José María Aznar, were defeated in this country’s elections after a 2004 terror attack that targeted a train in its capital. This country’s paramilitary Guardia Civil (“GWAR-dyah see-VEEL”) fought the ETA (“ET-ah”), which was dedicated to achieving independence for a region centered on this country’s city of Bilbao. For 10 points, name this country home to Basque and Catalan separatist groups.
answer: Spain [or España] <ML, European History>
formatted_text: In this country, 192 olive and cypress trees constitute a “Forest of Remembrance” that was created after a terrorist attack. After his assassination in a bombing, one politician from this country was nicknamed as this country’s “first astronaut.” In this country, a car was launched over a building during Operation Ogre, which assassinated a leader of the far right búnker faction, Luis (*) Carrero Blanco. The pro-Iraq War Popular Party and its leader, José María Aznar, were defeated in this country’s elections after a 2004 terror attack that targeted a train in its capital. This country’s paramilitary Guardia Civil (“GWAR-dyah see-VEEL”) fought the ETA (“ET-ah”), which was dedicated to achieving independence for a region centered on this country’s city of Bilbao. For 10 points, name this country home to Basque and Catalan separatist groups.

text: In 2018, this company was condemned after reports that it contracted the Lovelace Research Institute to conduct experiments on live Java monkeys. Three executives from this company were indicted in September 2019 for holding back market-moving information. For several years starting in 2009, this company programmed its TDI technology to recognize the EPA’s FTP-75 cycles, such that they would only activate controls in the laboratory and thus limit (*) engine output. As a result, those vehicles built by this company put out 40 times more nitrogen oxide in real life compared to during emissions testing, resulting in a scandal that brought down CEO Mark Winterkorn. For 10 points, name this German auto manufacturer whose former products include the Beetle.
answer: Volkswagen [prompt on VW] <WA, Other Academic>
formatted_text: In 2018, this company was condemned after reports that it contracted the Lovelace Research Institute to conduct experiments on live Java monkeys. Three executives from this company were indicted in September 2019 for holding back market-moving information. For several years starting in 2009, this company programmed its TDI technology to recognize the EPA’s FTP-75 cycles, such that they would only activate controls in the laboratory and thus limit (*) engine output. As a result, those vehicles built by this company put out 40 times more nitrogen oxide in real life compared to during emissions testing, resulting in a scandal that brought down CEO Mark Winterkorn. For 10 points, name this German auto manufacturer whose former products include the Beetle.

text: Geoffrey Elton’s book The Practice of History criticized E. H. Carr’s book What is History? for arbitrarily distinguishing between “historical” and “of the past” examples of these things. A sociological example of these things consists of institutions and norms external to an actor that constrain their actions. John Searle (“surl”) argued that collective intentionality, assignment of function, and constitutive (“CON-stih-TOO-tiv”) rules create the distinction between classes of these things labeled “brute” and “institutional.” The (*) Rules of Sociological Method, by Émile Durkheim (“ay-MEEL dur-KEM”), calls sociology the “science” of “social” examples of these things. Max Weber (“VAY-bur”) rejected the ethical naturalism of his contemporaries by upholding Hume’s distinction between these things and values. For 10 points, name these objectively true statements often contrasted with fictions.
answer: facts [accept social facts or historical facts or facts of the past or fact–value distinction] <AA, Social Science: Socio/Anthro>
formatted_text: Geoffrey Elton’s book The Practice of History criticized E. H. Carr’s book What is History? for arbitrarily distinguishing between “historical” and “of the past” examples of these things. A sociological example of these things consists of institutions and norms external to an actor that constrain their actions. John Searle (“surl”) argued that collective intentionality, assignment of function, and constitutive (“CON-stih-TOO-tiv”) rules create the distinction between classes of these things labeled “brute” and “institutional.” The (*) Rules of Sociological Method, by Émile Durkheim (“ay-MEEL dur-KEM”), calls sociology the “science” of “social” examples of these things. Max Weber (“VAY-bur”) rejected the ethical naturalism of his contemporaries by upholding Hume’s distinction between these things and values. For 10 points, name these objectively true statements often contrasted with fictions.
formatted_answer: facts [accept social facts or historical facts or facts of the past or fact–value distinction] <AA, Social Science: Socio/Anthro>

text: In “A Certain Tendency of the French Cinema,” François Truffaut (“true-FOH”) claims that a film of this title prompted the French to make Pépé le Moko in a “frank plagiarism of the American cinema.” That film of this title opens with screens asking “What are you going to do about it?” before segueing (“SEG-way-ing”) into a three-minute continuous shot, and was adapted from an Armitage Trail novel by Howard Hawks. Another film of this title cuts between shots of a man kissing a woman in a blue bikini in his car and of Angel’s face as he is (*) dismembered by a chainsaw. In that film of this title, a man asks “You wanna play rough?” before grabbing a grenade launcher and firing at Sosa’s men, yelling “Say hello to my little friend!” For 10 points, give this title of a 1983 Brian de Palma film that stars Al Pacino as a Cuban drug lord.
answer: Scarface <WA, Other Arts: Film>
formatted_text: In “A Certain Tendency of the French Cinema,” François Truffaut (“true-FOH”) claims that a film of this title prompted the French to make Pépé le Moko in a “frank plagiarism of the American cinema.” That film of this title opens with screens asking “What are you going to do about it?” before segueing (“SEG-way-ing”) into a three-minute continuous shot, and was adapted from an Armitage Trail novel by Howard Hawks. Another film of this title cuts between shots of a man kissing a woman in a blue bikini in his car and of Angel’s face as he is (*) dismembered by a chainsaw. In that film of this title, a man asks “You wanna play rough?” before grabbing a grenade launcher and firing at Sosa’s men, yelling “Say hello to my little friend!” For 10 points, give this title of a 1983 Brian de Palma film that stars Al Pacino as a Cuban drug lord.

text: A form of this property was discovered by Horst Prinzbach’s group while synthesizing dodecahedrane from pagodane (“puh-GO-dane”) derivatives. Anastrozole (“ann-ASS-truh-zole”) inhibits an enzyme named for this property that converts testosterone into estrogen. Molecules with this property have high chemical shifts for their hydrogen atoms due to the creation of a (*) diamagnetic current. The creation of this property is the reason why cyclopentadiene has an unusually low pKa (“P-K-A”) of 16. Molecules with this property have 4n-plus-2 pi electrons according to Hückel’s rule. For 10 points, name this kind of stability in a cyclic system with delocalized electrons, such as benzene.
answer: aromaticity [or aromatic compounds; prompt on resonance or delocalization or delocalized] <RN, Chemistry>
formatted_text: A form of this property was discovered by Horst Prinzbach’s group while synthesizing dodecahedrane from pagodane (“puh-GO-dane”) derivatives. Anastrozole (“ann-ASS-truh-zole”) inhibits an enzyme named for this property that converts testosterone into estrogen. Molecules with this property have high chemical shifts for their hydrogen atoms due to the creation of a (*) diamagnetic current. The creation of this property is the reason why cyclopentadiene has an unusually low pKa (“P-K-A”) of 16. Molecules with this property have 4n-plus-2 pi electrons according to Hückel’s rule. For 10 points, name this kind of stability in a cyclic system with delocalized electrons, such as benzene.
formatted_answer: aromaticity [or aromatic compounds; prompt on resonance or delocalization or delocalized] <RN, Chemistry>

text: When a messenger sent by this goddess killed a pheasant, the arrow landed at this goddess’s feet, after which a god standing next to her got pissed and threw the arrow into the messenger’s chest, killing him. This goddess, who employs a three-footed crow as a messenger, sent her grandson from the plain of heaven across a bridge to become the ruler of earth. In one story, her curiosity was piqued by the sound of laughter from several gods watching a bad (*) striptease performed on top of a bathtub. When this goddess sent Ninigi to rule earth, she gave him three gifts: a precious jewel, a “grasscutter” sword, and a mirror thought to be kept at the Ise (“ee-say”) shrine in which she saw her own reflection after emerging from a cave. For 10 points, name this sister of Susano’o who is the Shinto sun goddess.
answer: Amaterasu [or Amaterasu-no-Omikami] <WA, Myths/Legends>
formatted_text: When a messenger sent by this goddess killed a pheasant, the arrow landed at this goddess’s feet, after which a god standing next to her got pissed and threw the arrow into the messenger’s chest, killing him. This goddess, who employs a three-footed crow as a messenger, sent her grandson from the plain of heaven across a bridge to become the ruler of earth. In one story, her curiosity was piqued by the sound of laughter from several gods watching a bad (*) striptease performed on top of a bathtub. When this goddess sent Ninigi to rule earth, she gave him three gifts: a precious jewel, a “grasscutter” sword, and a mirror thought to be kept at the Ise (“ee-say”) shrine in which she saw her own reflection after emerging from a cave. For 10 points, name this sister of Susano’o who is the Shinto sun goddess.

text: Every year during this holiday, people meet on Cole’s Hill to commemorate Frank James’s speech on it. On this holiday, a Coast Guard blockade was blocked by Ron Craig’s ship, allowing John Trudell’s people to pass. Creedence Clearwater Revival supported that protest on this holiday with the donation of a boat. The UAINE created a National Day of Mourning on this holiday. After a letter campaign by (*) Sarah Josepha Hale to Abraham Lincoln, this holiday became a national holiday in 1864. Traditionally, Native American groups have protested it by painting Plymouth Rock red or occupying a replica of the Mayflower. For 10 points, name this holiday, commemorating Squanto’s sharing of food, celebrated on the fourth Thursday of November.
answer: Thanksgiving Day [accept National Day of Mourning until read; accept Unthanksgiving Day] <ML, US History>
formatted_text: Every year during this holiday, people meet on Cole’s Hill to commemorate Frank James’s speech on it. On this holiday, a Coast Guard blockade was blocked by Ron Craig’s ship, allowing John Trudell’s people to pass. Creedence Clearwater Revival supported that protest on this holiday with the donation of a boat. The UAINE created a National Day of Mourning on this holiday. After a letter campaign by (*) Sarah Josepha Hale to Abraham Lincoln, this holiday became a national holiday in 1864. Traditionally, Native American groups have protested it by painting Plymouth Rock red or occupying a replica of the Mayflower. For 10 points, name this holiday, commemorating Squanto’s sharing of food, celebrated on the fourth Thursday of November.
formatted_answer: Thanksgiving Day [accept National Day of Mourning until read; accept Unthanksgiving Day] <ML, US History>

text: The tail of a density distribution modelling one of these structures is often characterized by the “skin thickness,” across which that density drops from 90 percent to 10 percent. Danysz (“DAH-nish”) and Pniewski (“p’nee-EV-skee”) discovered one of these objects containing a hyperon. Maria Goeppert-Mayer (“GUR-putt-MY-er”) developed a model of these structures that allows for the prediction of a sequence of numbers characterizing them, including (*) 28, 50, 82, and 126. The motion of these objects is considered to be negligible in the Born–Oppenheimer approximation. The shell model describes these objects, which are particularly stable at “magic numbers.” The existence of these objects was deduced in an experiment in which alpha particles were fired at gold foil by Ernst Rutherford. For 10 points, name these structures composed of protons and neutrons.
answer: atomic nucleus [or atomic nuclei] <WA, Physics>
formatted_text: The tail of a density distribution modelling one of these structures is often characterized by the “skin thickness,” across which that density drops from 90 percent to 10 percent. Danysz (“DAH-nish”) and Pniewski (“p’nee-EV-skee”) discovered one of these objects containing a hyperon. Maria Goeppert-Mayer (“GUR-putt-MY-er”) developed a model of these structures that allows for the prediction of a sequence of numbers characterizing them, including (*) 28, 50, 82, and 126. The motion of these objects is considered to be negligible in the Born–Oppenheimer approximation. The shell model describes these objects, which are particularly stable at “magic numbers.” The existence of these objects was deduced in an experiment in which alpha particles were fired at gold foil by Ernst Rutherford. For 10 points, name these structures composed of protons and neutrons.

text: It’s not Spain, but a member of the political minority is compared to that of a bull and Christ as he dies in a story from this country by a member of its “Generation of 1837.” “The Slaughter Yard” and an earlier non-fiction book employ a dichotomy of “civilization and barbarism” to critique a dictator of this country. A character from this country goes on the run after killing a black man in a knife fight, leading him to be challenged by the man’s brother in an all-night singing contest. The Parisian (*) Serpent Club appears in a novel from this country that details Horacio Oliviera’s search for La Maga and includes a “Table of Instructions” explaining how it can be read nonlinearly. Martín Fierro and Julio Cortázar are from, for 10 points, what Latin American country, whose literature often features gauchos that roam the Pampas?
answer: Argentina [or Argentine Republic; or República Argentina] <AR, Misc Lit>
formatted_text: It’s not Spain, but a member of the political minority is compared to that of a bull and Christ as he dies in a story from this country by a member of its “Generation of 1837.” “The Slaughter Yard” and an earlier non-fiction book employ a dichotomy of “civilization and barbarism” to critique a dictator of this country. A character from this country goes on the run after killing a black man in a knife fight, leading him to be challenged by the man’s brother in an all-night singing contest. The Parisian (*) Serpent Club appears in a novel from this country that details Horacio Oliviera’s search for La Maga and includes a “Table of Instructions” explaining how it can be read nonlinearly. Martín Fierro and Julio Cortázar are from, for 10 points, what Latin American country, whose literature often features gauchos that roam the Pampas?

text: A 2019 Science paper reported the kinase PfCLK3 as a novel drug target in members of this genus. It’s not trypanosoma, but members of this genus have around 60 var genes that they can switch on and off to express different versions of their PfEMP1 protein on host cell surfaces. In host cells, this genus undergoes 13 to 14 rounds of cell division in schizogony (“skizz-OGG-uh-nee”), which ultimately produces a multinucleate schizont (“SKIZZ-ont”). An unusual peroxide bridge is found in a sesquiterpene (“SESS-qui-TER-peen”) lactone drug that treats infection by members of this genus, called (*) artemisinin. The ovale (“oh-VAL-ay”), vivax, and falciparum (“fal-SIP-uh-rum”) members of this genus most commonly infect humans, and are all carried by the common Anopheles (“uh-NOFF-uh-leez”) mosquito. For 10 points, name this genus of eukaryotes that are responsible for causing malaria.
answer: Plasmodium <RN, Biology: Immuno>
formatted_text: A 2019 Science paper reported the kinase PfCLK3 as a novel drug target in members of this genus. It’s not trypanosoma, but members of this genus have around 60 var genes that they can switch on and off to express different versions of their PfEMP1 protein on host cell surfaces. In host cells, this genus undergoes 13 to 14 rounds of cell division in schizogony (“skizz-OGG-uh-nee”), which ultimately produces a multinucleate schizont (“SKIZZ-ont”). An unusual peroxide bridge is found in a sesquiterpene (“SESS-qui-TER-peen”) lactone drug that treats infection by members of this genus, called (*) artemisinin. The ovale (“oh-VAL-ay”), vivax, and falciparum (“fal-SIP-uh-rum”) members of this genus most commonly infect humans, and are all carried by the common Anopheles (“uh-NOFF-uh-leez”) mosquito. For 10 points, name this genus of eukaryotes that are responsible for causing malaria.

text: The evolution of hereditary kingship among this region’s peoples is examined in a book that puts forth “Newton’s third law of empires” by Peter Heather. Those peoples of this region were divided into Ingaevones (“ing-eye-WO-nays”), Herminones (“hair-mih-NO-nays”), and Istaevones (“ist-eye-WO-nays”) by a classical author who described how a reputation as “lazy fools” had befallen the Cherusci (“khair-OO-skee”). An emperor supposedly bashed his head against the palace walls at night after a (*) defeat in this region, wailing “Quintilius Varus, give me back my legions!” This region titles an ethnography by Tacitus, who numbered the Marcomanni and Lombards among its peoples, and, like most Romans, roughly defined it as being north of the Danube and east of the Rhine. For 10 points, name this region where many Romans were slain at the Battle of Teutoburg Forest.
answer: Germania [or Germany] <JM, Ancient/Archaeology>
formatted_text: The evolution of hereditary kingship among this region’s peoples is examined in a book that puts forth “Newton’s third law of empires” by Peter Heather. Those peoples of this region were divided into Ingaevones (“ing-eye-WO-nays”), Herminones (“hair-mih-NO-nays”), and Istaevones (“ist-eye-WO-nays”) by a classical author who described how a reputation as “lazy fools” had befallen the Cherusci (“khair-OO-skee”). An emperor supposedly bashed his head against the palace walls at night after a (*) defeat in this region, wailing “Quintilius Varus, give me back my legions!” This region titles an ethnography by Tacitus, who numbered the Marcomanni and Lombards among its peoples, and, like most Romans, roughly defined it as being north of the Danube and east of the Rhine. For 10 points, name this region where many Romans were slain at the Battle of Teutoburg Forest.

text: Gunnar Kaufman excels in this activity before becoming a renowned poet and self-described “Black messiah” in Paul Beatty’s 1996 debut novel. The protagonist of a different novel dies of a heart attack while performing this activity in Florida, where he fled after having sex with his daughter-in-law. The protagonist uses his skill in this activity to stop a grenade from killing some Vietnamese children at an airport at the end of (*) A Prayer for Owen Meany. A novel opens with the 26-year-old protagonist stopping in an alley to participate in this activity with some teenagers before going home to his wife Janice. In a series of novels, a salesman who once excelled in this activity is depicted as “rich” and “at rest.” For 10 points, John Updike’s character Harry Angstrom is nicknamed “Rabbit” while a high-school star in what sport?
answer: basketball [accept descriptions such as shooting hoops or dunkin’ on ’em; prompt on sports] <RK, Long Fiction>
formatted_text: Gunnar Kaufman excels in this activity before becoming a renowned poet and self-described “Black messiah” in Paul Beatty’s 1996 debut novel. The protagonist of a different novel dies of a heart attack while performing this activity in Florida, where he fled after having sex with his daughter-in-law. The protagonist uses his skill in this activity to stop a grenade from killing some Vietnamese children at an airport at the end of (*) A Prayer for Owen Meany. A novel opens with the 26-year-old protagonist stopping in an alley to participate in this activity with some teenagers before going home to his wife Janice. In a series of novels, a salesman who once excelled in this activity is depicted as “rich” and “at rest.” For 10 points, John Updike’s character Harry Angstrom is nicknamed “Rabbit” while a high-school star in what sport?
formatted_answer: basketball [accept descriptions such as shooting hoops or dunkin’ on ’em; prompt on sports] <RK, Long Fiction>

text: This river is the ultimate drain of most of a highland region littered with many tabletop mountains called tepuis (“teh-POO-ees”). Competition from the spectacled caiman (“KAY-min”) has helped drive this river’s namesake species of huge crocodile to critically endangered status. This river’s name means “a place to paddle” in the language of the local Warao people, who travel on it in boats. The so-called Casiquiare (“ka-see-kee-AH-ray”) Canal flows [emphasize] south from this river into the (*) Rio Negro, linking it to a larger system to the south. This river provides most drainage to plains called the llanos (“YAH-nos”) and the rest of the area covered by the Guiana Shield. It empties into the Atlantic Ocean directly opposite from the island of Trinidad. For 10 points, name this major river of Venezuela.
answer: Orinoco River <WA, Geography>
formatted_text: This river is the ultimate drain of most of a highland region littered with many tabletop mountains called tepuis (“teh-POO-ees”). Competition from the spectacled caiman (“KAY-min”) has helped drive this river’s namesake species of huge crocodile to critically endangered status. This river’s name means “a place to paddle” in the language of the local Warao people, who travel on it in boats. The so-called Casiquiare (“ka-see-kee-AH-ray”) Canal flows [emphasize] south from this river into the (*) Rio Negro, linking it to a larger system to the south. This river provides most drainage to plains called the llanos (“YAH-nos”) and the rest of the area covered by the Guiana Shield. It empties into the Atlantic Ocean directly opposite from the island of Trinidad. For 10 points, name this major river of Venezuela.

text: This is the largest persistent feature that is confined by bands composed of Taylor columns, according to F. H. Busse’s “deep model.” In May 2019, amateur Anthony Wesley took a photo that appears to show “blades” and “flakes” on this feature, which is the largest such object in the “System II” latitude and has a “junior” counterpart called Oval BA. True color photos of this feature were taken at a distance of 8,000 kilometers in 2017 with the aid of an “auroral mapper” by NASA’s (*) Juno mission. The first observations to call it “permanent” were made by Giovanni Cassini. Time-lapse photos from Voyager 1 confirmed that this system, which is found between two jet streams and is about the diameter of the Earth, moves in an anticyclonic manner. For 10 points, name this large storm on Jupiter named for its color.
answer: Great Red Spot [prompt on spot; prompt on Jupiter or Jupiter’s atmosphere until “Jupiter” is read; prompt on the storm on Jupiter until “storm” is read] <WA, Astronomy>
formatted_text: This is the largest persistent feature that is confined by bands composed of Taylor columns, according to F. H. Busse’s “deep model.” In May 2019, amateur Anthony Wesley took a photo that appears to show “blades” and “flakes” on this feature, which is the largest such object in the “System II” latitude and has a “junior” counterpart called Oval BA. True color photos of this feature were taken at a distance of 8,000 kilometers in 2017 with the aid of an “auroral mapper” by NASA’s (*) Juno mission. The first observations to call it “permanent” were made by Giovanni Cassini. Time-lapse photos from Voyager 1 confirmed that this system, which is found between two jet streams and is about the diameter of the Earth, moves in an anticyclonic manner. For 10 points, name this large storm on Jupiter named for its color.
formatted_answer: Great Red Spot [prompt on spot; prompt on Jupiter or Jupiter’s atmosphere until “Jupiter” is read; prompt on the storm on Jupiter until “storm” is read] <WA, Astronomy>

text: A pink bird and several of these animals gather around a dark woman with glowing eyes in an Henri Rousseau painting with a solitary full moon at the top left. The pose of a reclining nude’s legs is mimicked by a pink one of these animals found to the right of two lions in another Rousseau painting, titled The Dream. A tiled blue wall decorated with calligraphy forms the background of a painting in which a nude boy with his back to the viewer holds two of these animals. That painting by (*) Jean-Léon Gérôme (“zhay-ROME”) titled for these animals is on the original cover of Edward Said’s (“sa-EED’s”) Orientalism. The ouroboros (“yur-uh-BOR-us”) symbol shows one of these animals, which feature in most scenes of The Death of Cleopatra. For 10 points, what kind of animal has an apple in its mouth in Henri Rousseau’s Eve?
answer: snake [accept serpent; accept specific varieties such as pythons or cobras or asps] <AR, Painting/Sculpture>
formatted_text: A pink bird and several of these animals gather around a dark woman with glowing eyes in an Henri Rousseau painting with a solitary full moon at the top left. A tiled blue wall decorated with calligraphy forms the background of a painting in which a nude boy with his back to the viewer holds two of these animals. That painting by (*) Jean-Léon Gérôme (“zhay-ROME”) titled for these animals is on the original cover of Edward Said’s (“sa-EED’s”) Orientalism. The ouroboros (“yur-uh-BOR-us”) symbol shows one of these animals, which feature in most scenes of The Death of Cleopatra. For 10 points, what kind of animal has an apple in its mouth in Henri Rousseau’s Eve?
formatted_answer: snake [accept serpent; accept specific varieties such as pythons or cobras or asps] <AR, Painting/Sculpture>

text: The third secret of Our Lady of Fátima predicted this country “spread[ing] her errors throughout the world” unless it was consecrated to the Immaculate Heart of Mary. Among this country’s many New Martyrs from the 20th century was a priest named Hermogenes. This country, which demolished the Church of Christ the Saviour to expropriate its gold, forced many of its youth to join the (*) League of Militant Atheists and set up many “anti-religious museums” as part of an effort to promote “scientific atheism.” This country failed in its plan to settle many Jews to the east in the Jewish Autonomous Oblast. For 10 points, name this country whose dominant Orthodox Church was answerable to the Communist Party of Leonid Brezhnev.
answer: Russia [or the Russian Federation or Russian Empire; or USSR; or Soviet Union; or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; or SSSR or Soyuz Sovietskikh Sotsialisticheskikh Respublik] <AA, Religion>
formatted_text: The third secret of Our Lady of Fátima predicted this country “spread[ing] her errors throughout the world” unless it was consecrated to the Immaculate Heart of Mary. For 10 points, name this country whose dominant Orthodox Church was answerable to the Communist Party of Leonid Brezhnev.
formatted_answer: Russia [or the Russian Federation or Russian Empire; or USSR; or Soviet Union; or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; or SSSR or Soyuz Sovietskikh Sotsialisticheskikh Respublik] <AA, Religion>

text: In bar 5 of an aria from an opera with this name in the title, three rising C major broken inverted triads in a dotted rhythm mimic a bugle or march. This name is sung in the middle of an aria that opens with a long C, repeats the short notes D B C three times, then falls from high E to low E. The overture of an opera titled for this name opens in D major with soft scurrying by unison strings and bassoons. The orchestra rests as this name quickly (*) repeats 9 times on the notes E D C in a baritone’s entrance aria announcing “make way.” This intrepid character from a Beaumarchais (“bo-mar-SHAY”) trilogy sings “Non più andrai” (“known pyoo on-DRY”) in Mozart’s first Da Ponte opera. This character helps Almaviva woo Rosina and sings “Largo al factotum” in Rossini’s Barber of Seville. For 10 points, name this protagonist of a Mozart comic opera about his “Marriage.”
answer: Figaro [accept Figaro’s aria; accept The Marriage of Figaro or Le nozze di Figaro; prompt on The Barber of Seville or Il barbiere di Siviglia or barber; prompt on “Largo al factotum” or factotum] <OL, Classical/Opera>
formatted_text: In bar 5 of an aria from an opera with this name in the title, three rising C major broken inverted triads in a dotted rhythm mimic a bugle or march. This name is sung in the middle of an aria that opens with a long C, repeats the short notes D B C three times, then falls from high E to low E. The overture of an opera titled for this name opens in D major with soft scurrying by unison strings and bassoons. The orchestra rests as this name quickly (*) repeats 9 times on the notes E D C in a baritone’s entrance aria announcing “make way.” This intrepid character from a Beaumarchais (“bo-mar-SHAY”) trilogy sings “Non più andrai” (“known pyoo on-DRY”) in Mozart’s first Da Ponte opera. This character helps Almaviva woo Rosina and sings “Largo al factotum” in Rossini’s Barber of Seville. For 10 points, name this protagonist of a Mozart comic opera about his “Marriage.”
formatted_answer: Figaro [accept Figaro’s aria; accept The Marriage of Figaro or Le nozze di Figaro; prompt on The Barber of Seville or Il barbiere di Siviglia or barber; prompt on “Largo al factotum” or factotum] <OL, Classical/Opera>

text: This poem employs the image of a bishop “waving a condom full of black-beetles” in a hell “without dignity, without tragedy.” Lord Palmerston advises, “Begin where you are” in a section of this poem that heavily cites the Confucian Book of Rites. The first Bollingen Prize was awarded to a section of this poem, whose “Fifth Decad” includes a piece arguing that Renaissance artists prospered only in a world without usura. This poem, whose (*) “China” section quotes many Chinese ideograms, begins “And then went down to the ship” and is divided into sections like “Rock Drill.” After its author was arrested for pro-Fascist broadcasts over Rome Radio, he wrote a section of this poem while imprisoned in Pisa. For 10 points, name this book-length Modernist poem by Ezra Pound.
answer: The Cantos <NC, Poetry>
formatted_text: This poem employs the image of a bishop “waving a condom full of black-beetles” in a hell “without dignity, without tragedy.” Lord Palmerston advises, “Begin where you are” in a section of this poem that heavily cites the Confucian Book of Rites. The first Bollingen Prize was awarded to a section of this poem, whose “Fifth Decad” includes a piece arguing that Renaissance artists prospered only in a world without usura. This poem, whose (*) “China” section quotes many Chinese ideograms, begins “And then went down to the ship” and is divided into sections like “Rock Drill.” After its author was arrested for pro-Fascist broadcasts over Rome Radio, he wrote a section of this poem while imprisoned in Pisa. For 10 points, name this book-length Modernist poem by Ezra Pound.

text: This politician published an article declaring “We want no Caesars” decrying his own rise to power under the pseudonym “Chanakya.” The Henderson Brooks report claimed that this politician’s military was underprepared for a war that was preceded by his Forward Policy. A scandal involving procurement of jeeps during that war led this leader’s defense minister, V. K. (*) Menon, to resign. Groups like the Monkees and the Beatles popularized this leader’s namesake style of jacket in the 1960s. This man claimed that “The light has gone out of our lives” after the assassination of his mentor by Nathuram Godse and gave the “Tryst with Destiny” speech after his country gained independence from the UK in 1947. For 10 points, name this first prime minister of India.
answer: Jawaharlal Nehru <ML, World History>
formatted_text: This politician published an article declaring “We want no Caesars” decrying his own rise to power under the pseudonym “Chanakya.” The Henderson Brooks report claimed that this politician’s military was underprepared for a war that was preceded by his Forward Policy. A scandal involving procurement of jeeps during that war led this leader’s defense minister, V. K. (*) Menon, to resign. Groups like the Monkees and the Beatles popularized this leader’s namesake style of jacket in the 1960s. This man claimed that “The light has gone out of our lives” after the assassination of his mentor by Nathuram Godse and gave the “Tryst with Destiny” speech after his country gained independence from the UK in 1947. For 10 points, name this first prime minister of India.

text: The traditional costume of men in this country is a toga-like cloth whose name means “holy,” called the jard. Dozens of this country’s people still die each year from landmines in its Nafusa Mountains and other regions. To honor the photojournalist Tim Hetherington, this country’s city of Ajdabiya (“ahj-da-BEE-ya”) named a square after him. Sabha (“SEB-ha”), the largest city within this country’s poor (*) Fezzan region, is one of many cities containing newly opened slave markets in the past decade. One of the two major factions in this country’s ongoing civil war is headquartered at Tobruk. This country re-adopted its traditional red, green, and black flag in 2011, replacing an all-green one. For 10 points, name this country whose non-Tobruk government is located in Tripoli.
answer: Libya [or State of Libya] <WA, Geography>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses

Sabha (“SEB-ha”), the largest city within this country’s poor (*) Fezzan region, is one of many cities containing newly opened slave markets in the past decade. text: Herodotus states that the Scythians sent one of these animals along with a bird, a mouse, and five arrows to Darius as a threatening gift. In one of Aesop’s fables, a stork begins devouring these animals after they pray to Zeus to receive a king. A mock-epic falsely attributed to Homer describes a battle between these animals and mice. These animals exclaim “That’s right, Mr. Busybody, right!” in a work that begins as a god argues whether he should complain about an aching shoulder or a bellyache with his servant (*) Xanthias. These animals sing and mock Charon while he rows in that play, repeating the line “Brekekekex koax koax.” Dionysus tries to retrieve Euripides from the underworld in an Aristophanes play titled after, for 10 points, what croaking amphibians?
answer: frogs [or batrachoi or ranae] <RR, Myths/Legends>
formatted_text: Herodotus states that the Scythians sent one of these animals along with a bird, a mouse, and five arrows to Darius as a threatening gift. In one of Aesop’s fables, a stork begins devouring these animals after they pray to Zeus to receive a king. A mock-epic falsely attributed to Homer describes a battle between these animals and mice. These animals exclaim “That’s right, Mr. Busybody, right!” in a work that begins as a god argues whether he should complain about an aching shoulder or a bellyache with his servant (*) Xanthias. These animals sing and mock Charon while he rows in that play, repeating the line “Brekekekex koax koax.” Dionysus tries to retrieve Euripides from the underworld in an Aristophanes play titled after, for 10 points, what croaking amphibians?

text: For use in “The Dry Salvages (“sal-VAY-jizz”),” T. S. Eliot simplified this poem’s phrase “the deep / Moans round with many voices,” after calling it “too poetical” in his essay “Dante.” In this poem, the speaker notes “how dull it is” to “rust unburnish’d, not to shine in use!” and intends to “drink / Life to the lees.” In the second of this poem’s three stanzas, the speaker introduces his son, who “works his work” and is given the (*) “sceptre and the isle.” This poem opens with its speaker near a “still hearth (“harth”), among these barren crags, / Match’d with an aged wife.” This dramatic monologue ends with the speaker describing himself as “Made weak by time and fate, but strong in will / To strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield.” For 10 points, name this poem by Alfred, Lord Tennyson, spoken by a king of Ithaca.
answer: “Ulysses” <NC, Poetry>
formatted_text: For use in “The Dry Salvages (“sal-VAY-jizz”),” T. S. Eliot simplified this poem’s phrase “the deep / Moans round with many voices,” after calling it “too poetical” in his essay “Dante.” In this poem, the speaker notes “how dull it is” to “rust unburnish’d, not to shine in use!” and intends to “drink / Life to the lees.” In the second of this poem’s three stanzas, the speaker introduces his son, who “works his work” and is given the (*) “sceptre and the isle.” This poem opens with its speaker near a “still hearth (“harth”), among these barren crags, / Match’d with an aged wife.” This dramatic monologue ends with the speaker describing himself as “Made weak by time and fate, but strong in will / To strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield.” For 10 points, name this poem by Alfred, Lord Tennyson, spoken by a king of Ithaca.

text: This letter is found in the prefix of the name of a molecule used as the starting point of heme and chlorophyll biosynthesis, called aminolevulenic acid, or ALA. Lactones and lactase with this letter preceding their name contain 6-membered heterocyclic rings. Lanthanide-based reagents such as EuFOD are used to improve the resolution of a quantity symbolized by this letter. That quantity denoted by this letter, which is often calibrated against a trimethylsilane standard, is called the (*) chemical shift and is vital in NMR. The addition of heat in a chemical reaction is symbolized by writing this letter over the reaction arrow. The lowercase version of this letter is used to represent partial charges in polar bonds. For 10 points, name this Greek letter whose uppercase version represents the change in quantities like free energy and entropy.
answer: delta <RN, Chemistry>
formatted_text: This letter is found in the prefix of the name of a molecule used as the starting point of heme and chlorophyll biosynthesis, called aminolevulenic acid, or ALA. Lactones and lactase with this letter preceding their name contain 6-membered heterocyclic rings. Lanthanide-based reagents such as EuFOD are used to improve the resolution of a quantity symbolized by this letter. That quantity denoted by this letter, which is often calibrated against a trimethylsilane standard, is called the (*) chemical shift and is vital in NMR. The addition of heat in a chemical reaction is symbolized by writing this letter over the reaction arrow. The lowercase version of this letter is used to represent partial charges in polar bonds. For 10 points, name this Greek letter whose uppercase version represents the change in quantities like free energy and entropy.

text: One of these dances in G minor by Franz Liszt begins with a steady crescendo as the left and right hand play presto triplets rising from the piano’s lowest register, and is part of a supplement to the second suite of Years of Pilgrimage. The name of this dance supposedly originated after performers disturbed a priest of the church of St. Magnus. This dance is used in the finale of Schubert’s String Quartet No. 14, “Death and the Maiden.” This dance in 6/8 (“six-eight”) time, and the related (*) saltarello, are found in the finale of Felix Mendelssohn’s Symphony No. 4. This dance may be named for a city in Apulia whose women performed it furiously to sweat venom out of their pores. For 10 points, name this frenzied Italian dance whose name indicates that it could supposedly cure a hairy spider’s bite.
answer: tarantella [or tarantelle; or tarantello] <WA, Classical/Opera>
formatted_text: One of these dances in G minor by Franz Liszt begins with a steady crescendo as the left and right hand play presto triplets rising from the piano’s lowest register, and is part of a supplement to the second suite of Years of Pilgrimage. The name of this dance supposedly originated after performers disturbed a priest of the church of St. Magnus. This dance is used in the finale of Schubert’s String Quartet No. 14, “Death and the Maiden.” This dance in 6/8 (“six-eight”) time, and the related (*) saltarello, are found in the finale of Felix Mendelssohn’s Symphony No. 4. This dance may be named for a city in Apulia whose women performed it furiously to sweat venom out of their pores. For 10 points, name this frenzied Italian dance whose name indicates that it could supposedly cure a hairy spider’s bite.
